One of Nina SimoneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s finest recordings, this Colpix LP features the unique singer/pianist performing classic versions of Ã¢â‚¬Å“Black Is the Color of My True LoveÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Hair,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Ã¢â‚¬Å“The Other Woman,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ and Ã¢â‚¬Å“Wild Is the Wind.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ With supportive work from bassist Jimmy Bond and drummer Albert Ã¢â‚¬Å“TootieÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ Heath, she also sounds fine on a few instrumentals. 1962 Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Nina Simone Sings Ellington

Nina Simone was on her way to becoming a major name by 1962, with her protest and civil rights songs giving her acclaim and recognition far beyond the jazz world. This CD reissue is a change of pace for the singer/pianist, who is heard performing 11 songs written by Duke Ellington and/or Billy Strayhorn. Backed by an unidentified string orchestra (the accompaniment is often sparse) and the Malcolm Dodds Singers, she not only revives the usual Duke hits but such obscurities as Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, Buddy Bolden,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Ã¢â‚¬Å“Merry Mending,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ and Ã¢â‚¬Å“You Better Know It.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ None of these performances sound like the typical treatment of Ellington material, with Ã¢â‚¬Å“I Got It BadÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ having a gospel feel, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Something to Live ForÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ being brief but heartfelt, Ã¢â‚¬Å“I Like the SunriseÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ sounding like a big production number, and Ã¢â‚¬Å“Satin DollÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ being taken as an instrumental. The brevity of this CD is unfortunate and this project should have been combined with another former LP, but what is here is quite intriguing and original.

1964 Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Folksy Nina

Like the 1963 LP Nina Simone at Carnegie Hall, this was recorded at Carnegie Hall on May 12, 1963, but duplicates little of the material found on that prior album. It isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t just unworthy leftovers, but a strong set in its own right, concentrating on material that could be seen as traditional or folk in orientation. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not exactly strictly folk music, in repertoire or arrangement (which includes piano, guitar, bass, and drums, though not every tune has all of the instruments); Ã¢â‚¬Å“Twelfth of NeverÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ (which had also appeared on the Carnegie Hall LP) certainly isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t folk music. However, there was also an uptempo piano blues, LeadbellyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Ã¢â‚¬Å“Silver City BoundÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½; covers of the Israeli Ã¢â‚¬Å“Erets Zavat ChalavÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ and Ã¢â‚¬Å“VanetihuÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ which served as further proof that SimoneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s eclecticism knew no bounds; and the stark, moody, spiritually shaded ballads at which she excelled (Ã¢â‚¬Å“When I Was a Young Girl,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hush Little BabyÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½). Ã¢â‚¬Å“Lass of the Low CountryÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is as exquisitely sad-yet-beautiful as it gets. The album has been combined with another Colpix LP, Nina Simone with Strings, on a single-disc CD reissue by Collectables.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

5CD set collects five of her original albums, in card LP replica sleeves. Features Ã¢â‚¬Å“The Amazing Nina SimoneÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ (1959), Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nina Simone At Town HallÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ (1959), Ã¢â‚¬Å“Forbidden FruitÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ (1960), Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nina Simone Sings EllingtonÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ (1962) and Ã¢â‚¬Å“Folksy NinaÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ (1964).
Nina Simone was one of the most gifted vocalists of her generation, and also one of the most eclectic. Simone was a singer, pianist, and songwriter who bent genres to her will rather than allowing herself to be confined by their boundaries; her work swung back and forth between jazz, blues, soul, R&B, pop, gospel, and world music, with passion, emotional honesty, and a strong grasp of technique as the constants of her musical career. Nina was born Eunice Kathleen Waymon in Tryon, North Carolina on February 21, 1933.
